Source 2Estimated Number of African American Migrants Leaving the United States South by Decade

All values are approximate.

The data for the 10 bars are as follows:

1900s: 200,000 migrants

1910s: 440,000 migrants

1920s: 810,000 migrants

1930s: 390,000 migrants

1940s: 1,450,000 migrants

1950s: 1,110,000 migrants

1960s: 1,000,000 migrants

1970s: 800,000 migrants

1980s: 600,000 migrants

1990s: 510,000 migrants
Adapted from James N. Gregory, America’s Great Migrations Project
content.question: Which of the following statements about Black migration during the 1920s and 1940s does the chart best support?

choices.label: The realities of urban life in northern cities led to a sustained decline in migrants leaving the South.
The availability of factory jobs in the North led to an eventual increase in migrants leaving the South.
The advances made by the Civil Rights movement led to a reduction in the number of migrants leaving the South.
The appeal of the Harlem Renaissance led to a substantial increase in migrants leaving the South.

content.answer: The availability of factory jobs in the North led to an eventual increase in migrants leaving the South.
